results.title: Energy, food and exercise
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Film Corporation, Barry Pierce and Roger Lupton
results.brief_description: A humorous presentation equating the human body with a machine. Raises issues about the effects of lifestyle on health, bodyweight and fitness. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Energy Victoria
results.brief_description: A brief promotional overview of the corporate activities of Energy Victoria. Services highlighted are those which assist clients to conserve energy and allow for the development of renewable resources. There is no dialogue but the images are accompanied by a soundtrack.

results.title: Energy unlimited: nuclear research at Lucas Heights
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian Atomic Energy Commission
results.brief_description: The history of the Atomic Research Establishment at Lucas Heights near Sydney and a description of its work in atomic research and in producing radio-isotopes for industry and medicine. Includes the construction of the buildings; the official opening by the Prime Minister, the Rt. Hon. R.G. Menzies in 1958; the functioning of the research reactor.

results.title: Energy management for the future
results.creator_credit: Melvana Communications Group, ONF | NFB, Patrick Loubert and Michael Melnyk
results.brief_description: Our society is rapidly depleting its energy bank. This film creates awareness of the seriousness of the situation, what measures the federal government has taken, and how each one of us can help slow down the rapid consumption of non-renewable resources.

results.title: Energy in perspective
results.creator_credit: Peter De Normanville, Douglas Gordon and Balfour Films
results.brief_description: Looks at the history of energy sources, the effect the industrial revolution had on the use of energy in all forms, its increasing use today, the need for conservation of power sources and the research being undertaken today in all parts of the world into new sources of energy

results.title: Energy highway
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Peter Johnson and Dennis Hill Productions
results.brief_description: This film shows the construction of a natural gas pipeline stretching half way across Australia. Made for the Pipeline Authority, this film shows the immensity of the task and the people involved in achieving this feat

results.title: Energy from the sun
results.brief_description: Animated and live-action sequences are used to explain the water cycle and to show how solar energy is transformed, transmitted through space, utilised by man and by plants, and stored for future use. Shows the work of scientists in converting the sun’s energy into industrial power. Includes an exploratory visit to the sun by means of telescopic stop-motion photography.

results.title: Energy from the atom
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and Atomic Energy of Canada
results.brief_description: This film offers audiences a clear illustration of how an atomic reactor produces electricity. Special features of the Canadian CANDU (Canada Deuterium Uranium) system are explained: on-power refuelling; the use of natural uranium; the use of heavy water as moderator. CANDU is recognized internationally as a leader in the search for new sources of energy.

results.title: Energy for the future
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Bert Van Bork
results.brief_description: Examines energy alternatives for the future, including processed coal, shale oil, geothermal heat, nuclear fission and fusion, wind and solar heat. Many of these sources already supply part of our country’s energy needs - but some with accompanying social and environmental consequences

results.title: Energy everlasting
results.brief_description: Everyone knows that oil won’t last forever. The search for new forms of renewable energy is increasing. This film looks at some of the ways that are being used to explore the options available. In Indonesia and the Phillipines photo voltaics provide electricity for homes. In Sweden, biomass and hydroelectricity play an increasing role, and in other parts of the world, wind and wave power are playing their part. The costs of these systems are as yet untested in a harsh fiscal world but, in the next thirty years, some of these fledgling technologies will come more and more to the fore.
